segments.text: 15th of July, sitting at 2720 Camelot and Bryan in a very comfortable, looks like a TV room, with Colonel Joe T. Haney, about to chat with him about his experiences, particularly with the A&M Band.
Hello, here I am sitting with Haskell watching the new patio we just put in the back and it's such a beautiful day and we're both glad to be here and we hope this is a fruitful experience.
Let's begin with your briefly summarizing your experience
growing up and going to college and so forth, before going to high school and all, before you came to A&M?
Where was home?

my home is in marlin texas and i was a product of the marlin public schools and i graduated from marlin high school and upon graduation in may my mother packed me up in my uh with my foot locker and sent me to texas a m and i became a fish in the texas aggie band and i lived in bezell hall what this was the summer of 1944 and uh i was

in the band that summer and then after the end of the summer well I have vacated A&M and I had to prepare myself to go into the service you know the war was going on then when you're 18 years old you're gone and so I entered the
the armed services, the army.

I went to Sam Houston for basic training and then at this point in time I was offered an opportunity to go to officer's training school which I could see in 19, right at 1945 that the war was near completion so I decided not to go that route.
I stayed in there for two years.
I spent 14 months in Korea.
When I was in Korea, I played in the 282nd AGF band and was stationed in Seoul, Korea.

lived in the Red Cross building and we had a rehearsed every day and every afternoon before the movie for all the troops there in Seoul we would play a concert four days a week we would play with a concert band and three days a week we would play with a large dance band or stage band and
So I got some marvelous experience, and I stayed over there about 14 months.
Then upon arrival back in the United States with my honorable discharge in my hand, I decided to study music, which I could not do at A&M, so I went to Southern Methodist University.
In 1950, I got a Bachelor of Music there, and then started teaching band.
My first band job was in Hemp Hill, Texas.
Started the band there.
It was the only one I could find in the state of Texas that had not had a band before because I wanted to learn about twice as much as they did, which I did.
At that point, I got this marvelous offer to go to Calvert, Texas.
Calvert was really a blow-and-go in town in those days.
I was a counselor at a boys' camp in Rio Vista.
I had the president of the school board signing Calvert.
And he hired me on the spot, and so I stayed in Calvert for four years, which were very fruitful years.
So that would have been 1950.
That was 1951 to 1955, I believe.
And we had a real good band in Calvert, which they had not had before, but we did a lot of work and growing.
And I decided that I needed to go to a larger system, so I went to Wharton, Texas, as the band director.
And I stayed there only one year, and the job at Mahea opened.
And I went there with Mr. Alton Bowen, who eventually became the head of the Texas Education Agency and was also the superintendent of schools here in Bryan.
And so I moved to Mejia with Mr. Bowen.
And I stayed there 16 years.
And they were very fruitful years.
And we had an outstanding band program there.
And from there, I came to A&M in 1972.
Colonel Adams, who was the director of the Aggie band, and I had been friends for years and years before this took place.
We used to hunt quail a lot, and our band and the Aggie band did exactly the same kind of 65 precision marching.
And so we decided, Mary and I decided that this was a great move and so we moved to Bryan in 1972 and I became the associate director of the Fightin' Texas Aggie Band.
And in 1973 when Byrne retired, well I became the director of the Aggie Band and that was certainly a marvelous experience to
just continue the work in the 65 precision marching that I had been doing for all those years.
I was a high school band director for 22 years before I came to Texas A&M.
So I was not just somebody that fell off the turnip truck.
I kind of knew what I was talking about.

Our bands in Mejia had been consistent sweepstakes bands all those years and we had many many many students in the Allstate band and we had quite a few that went on to study music and become band directors and besides that in Mejia I had 31 places I could hunt quail and and had a nice golf course to play.
Mary and I both had carts and six or eight wonderful places to fish and it was just it was a marvelous experience there.

but of course as soon as I got used at A&M got used to the fact that driving up to the big buildings and parking in my own parking place well then we began to settle down and do the work at hand and so I stayed then at Texas A&M for 17 years
and I retired in 1989 and after having 41 years in teacher's retirement so I've had a full life directing bands in the state of Texas.
Splendid.
Did that brief, let's see you were here as a student only one summer?
One summer, that is correct.
Did that get embedded in your heart deeply?
Well, I had that a lot earlier, Haskell, because all of my family on one side had graduated from A&M.
And they were dyed into wool laggies, and I was bleeding maroon when I was 10 years old.
And I really, that's the only place that I wanted to go.
But now when I came in the summer of 1944, I studied accounting.

and that was what I had maybe a CPA or something of that nature and I decided that that's not what I wanted to do and and so that's the main reason I did not come back but it has always been deep in my heart and of course
The Aggie band has always been my favorite band in this world.
And when I became a director down here, well then it was my number one interest other than my family and Marion.
And I just have had this maroon all my life I guess, this maroon blood, and I just don't guess I will ever get it out of my system.
Now that brief experience in the Army with a band, that was primarily a performance band, not much marching?
Well it was, we were there in Korea.
I played in several bands.
through basic and just the post bands and then when I went to I decided not to go to officers training school then they sent me to Fort Monmouth New Jersey and I became a radio operator
And I played in a very fine band up there.
We played for the likes of Big Damone and several others while I was there.
And then when I went overseas, the radio operator's job was not a pleasant thing.
They would send us up in these mountains where it was about 15 below, and you'd send code back and forth.
And the communists there did not know that the war was over.

and it was not very much fun so the first pass that I received I went to Sewell and I saw this big band sitting up there on that stage playing this broadcast and I said oh my goodness wouldn't that be marvelous so I go in and talk to the Lieutenant Miller who was in charge of the band and he played with the Dorsey Orchestra and the New York Philharmonic
And he asked me what I played.
I told him.
And he said, well, would you be interested in moving over here?
And I said, I certainly would.
He said, are you good?
I said, yes, sir, I am.
He said, well, I want to hear you because our first trombone player just left and went back to the States and we don't have one there.
So I go on trombone.

so i go back there and audition for him and he said you'll be here next monday if you want to come i said yes sir i do and next monday there was a jeep waiting for me about six in the morning to take me to sewell and i stayed there most i stayed there about 13 months in that band it was a marvelous band and he was a marvelous man and on saturday he would give us uh
arranging a little course in arranging and composing and chords and musical facts that we needed to know to be a composer and arranger.
And I really enjoyed that.
And I think that's the main thing that

that made me change my mind as to what I wanted to be and I still thank a lot of him and I'm sure he's passed away but he was such a fine man and such a fine musician and he really influenced my life and what I wanted to do.
And the military style marching, the six to five, so that came kind of naturally.
In high school did you all?
Well in high school we did not really march to the yard lines.
You know now they march to the yard lines.
You take six steps to the yard lines every yard line and you hit that with your six steps and that's the main way that we stay in line.
You march a 30-inch step in the service, and of course I liked that, and I didn't like the high-stepping, prancing things, and my high school band was really quite good at that.
We marched and did many things.
We were on television five times just because we were good, not because our football team was good.
And we marched at the Cotton Bowl and things of this nature, played for the governor several times.
And that was fascinating to me, the things that you could do with a group just on a football field.

But if those lines, when they start putting the lines in, and the main reason they did that is mostly for the bands, because the football fields years ago were just lined off every 10 yards, some of them every 20 yards.
And so then they started putting it in and it just simplified everything and gave the bands a larger opportunity to do a lot of difficult things.
And so I just loved that and I did all of the drills myself for 17 years and I just got a big kick out of doing them.
I just really enjoyed it.

Doing it and watching them doing it and then to see to see if it worked out real good and usually it did they those guys are all smart and they they could play well and You put those two together with a good drill and you just have something that's really nice to watch Now your SMU band experience it was They played they were they were they played the football band played jazz most of the time and they were high steppers and I did it

and but I also played in the symphonic band and I played in several brass choirs and things of this nature and I studied privately on the horn and that was mostly a learning experience on playing and I was trying to learn how to
Teach all the other students in the school when I when I started teaching how to play all the instruments I had to learn how to play all the brass instruments all the woodwind instruments.
I had a lesson in percussion in strings and So this was more or less an educational experience.
Although it was a nice musical experience.
We had some great players there but the I just marched in the in the Mustang band because I Had to do it was one of the main reasons I had to do it and I wanted to do it
And I like jazz.
I like the jazz that they play.
And so I really enjoyed that up there.
And then in Sam Houston, when I got my master's degree, it was more or less just a continuation of what we were doing.
And I also played in the Houstonian, which was their jazz band down there.
And I got my tuition for the summer there playing in that band.
But the marching, 65 marching came when I came to Mahea.
I had not done that.
The East Texas bands over there do it, and they still do it.
And I had the first National Association of Military Marching Band contest here, which I was one of the founders of that.
And we had 24 bands, and the requirements were that you played
a military-oriented music, and you had to march in military style.
And if you did not meet these requirements, you couldn't enter.
And the first year we had it at Kyle Field, we had 24 bands there, and at the presentations, we had about 14,000, 15,000 people to see it.
So the Aggie Band performed just as an exhibition thing, and they've been having it ever since.
That was in 1988, the first one was held at A&M.
And that was quite an experience for everybody.
And so the military bands in the high schools are still going.
They're very strong in East Texas.
And you'll see them scattered around, but in East Texas, they're very, very strong.

they're still having that contest although they can't have it here anymore because of the grass field they won't let them have it on the grass so let's see for trivia what was your pay that beginning year that first year at hemp hill the first year i taught school at hemp hill i made twenty four hundred dollars for the first year
And most of them want to make that now the first week.
But that's all I had.
And with my first paycheck, I bought me a horse.
And I had money in the bank.
And I had a car and a set of golf clubs.
And I saved money.
So things were a lot different then.
But that was the basic pay for all teachers in 1950.
And that's what I received was the base pay.
And they moved a school building into Hemphill.
And they had no horns.
They had no uniforms.
They had no music.
And the superintendent said, I'm going to give you $2,000 and you just buy all them horns you need.
And so we had to make a few adjustments.
But I have pictures of the band.
I started the first concert we played at the end of the year.
We had 54 and they all had on uniforms.
That was quite an experience too.
I've had some marvelous experiences with bands.
Now as you got closer to here, reach back and describe Colonel Adams as a person and his style and manner.
Colonel Adams and I hunted quail for years and years and he always seemed very interested in me personally and my band personally and he would come to the marching contest and see us and he was very

very strict with his uh his his marching cadence and he the Aggie band marches 104 steps per minute and he liked he liked for the bands to be slower and I do too I did too we marched about 112 in my high school but for instance the the normal cadence of review was 120. and so when I came here
That was the cadence that they were using strictly because it was Army regulations.
Well, Colonel Tom Parsons and I, there was always a conflag between the Corps and the band because of the faster cadence.
So I went to see him one day and said, now there's no

uh... provisions anywhere for somebody wearing senior boots they cannot march a hundred and twenty and so we we cut it to a hundred and twelve and it's made the review so much better and they're still doing that but colonel adams was a very strict man he was uh... uh... he he was a a very fair man and uh... he was certainly an honest man and uh... he did a he did a fine job with this with the aggie band they

uh... and and all of the men uh... appeared to like him very very much and he was a very popular person I think he was here for twenty seven years and I think I was the third band director full time band director that they had in the history of the school so from nineteen twenty three to nineteen eighty nine I believe they had three band directors and that speaks highly for the job I think and so we
We would always meet, Colonel Adams and I and Mary and his wife Belle.
We'd meet at the TBA, the Texas Band Marital Association.
We'd go out to eat.
So we were very, very close friends for I guess 20 years before I came to A&M.
And he ran a tight ship, I'll tell you that for sure.
And everybody conformed to his way of doing it.
And his way was the good way, because they were very successful in what they did.
And so I was, our relationship was very, very good, and we really loved to hunt birds together.
I wrote, he called me in about 1968, and he said, I want you to do something for me.
And I said, well, certainly I'll do something for you.
He said, I want you to rewrite The Spirit of Aggieland.
And I said, rewrite it or rearrange it?
He said, I want you to rearrange it.
He said, we are playing against Texas Tech, Texas, some of those big bands, and this is the arrangement that was written in 1923 by Colonel Dunn, and it's got to be beefed up.
And I said, well, let me try it and see what happens.
When I received the arrangement they had, well most of it was in two-part harmony.
So that was the first thing we corrected.
We put it in three-part harmony and what we wanted was to get
the same idea, but a much bigger, fuller sound.
And he said, between the yell and the last strain, I want you to put in a little trumpeting thing, something different.
He said, we just sit there and we just play.
And you'd have to know him to really understand it.
I said, well, I think I have an idea what you mean.
So anyway, I wrote the arrangement.
And I played it with my band, and it sounded real good to me.
So anyway, I sent it to him.

and I didn't hear him that was in the summer of 68 I did not hear anything from him and I said well I guess I guess he didn't like it I guess uh uh he didn't he didn't want to use it and I was playing golf one Saturday at in my hair with my friends and one of them just died in a little lag he had his radio on he's listening to the game between shots and I heard this
this bugling that I put in there, and I said, my goodness, he's used that arrangement.
And they have been playing it now since 1968, and that's 20, what?
31 years.
And they're still playing that thing.
So he called me back again, and he said, well, that was good.
He said, I've got to have something with a little pep in it.
He said, we've got nothing but marches and no, I need something with some pep.
So anyway, I wrote him a song.
And we were walking along one day, and he said, have you ever heard Step to the Rear?
We were hunting.
I said, yes, I have.
So we walked another 100 yards, and we sat down on a rock, and he said, have you ever heard Hey, Look Me Over?
I said, yes, I have.
He said, well, then when you write that song, I want it to be somewhere between Step to the Rear and Hey, Look Me Over.
I said, well, okay, I think I know what you mean.
So I wrote this tune.
I called it Gig'Em.
And he said, well, you want to name it that?
I said, well, whatever you want to name it.
I just thought that'd be a good one.
So that's what they named it.
And he put it on his album that he made that fall.
And we played that up until just a few years ago.
And now we don't play that anymore.
But anyway, those were the two songs that I gave him.

he said well he called me once i want to pay you for those i said i don't want any money for those because that's something i just want to do and he said well i'll either give you money or a bird dog i said well give me a bird dog because then you give me money i'll just spend it so i got a bird dog had the dog 11 years and he was really good
So, you know, I think we had a real fine relationship before I came to A&M, and the fact I think that, well, there's no question in anybody's mind, if he had not wanted me, I would not be there.
Now where did he do his training and preparation?
He went to Texas A&M and he got his degree there, and then he went to Vandercook, the same place that Jay Brewer, the associate director now, went to get a music degree.
I think it's in Chicago.
And he was a high school band director.
He was at Paris, I think, one year, and then I think he was down at Humber one year.
I believe he was.
And then at that time, if you'll remember, it was mandatory that you retired at 65.
And that's the only reason he retired.
And so, you know, I was just 43.
44 or whatever I was, 44, 45, and I had no earthly desire to retire.
And so then this seemed like the thing to do to me, and we had a great 17 years.
I just wouldn't take anything for it.
When you arrived, describe the facilities for the band in terms of practice and instruments that the institution owned.
All right.
They had just built a new band hall.
one that they have now it's called the E.V.

Adams Band Building and it was an excellent facility except it had Rogers in it at that time and it was really too small for uh after the the second the first year I was here we had close to 300 then after that we had 300 for a long time and before that they they uh practiced in dorm 11 and they had one of the walls knocked so they just had
They had two walls.
That's where they practiced on the fourth floor of dorm 11.
And so the facility was fine.

there was a i believe when i came here in 72 there were about 15 000 people at a m and i believe we had about three four thousand girls i'm not sure i'm don't quote me on that i think that's about right but there was a real need for some additional instrumental music uh
That was one of the first things that I encountered when I came, all these people I'd never heard of, and I couldn't do anything.
I just didn't even know, barely knew how to get to the band hall.
But they wanted some instrumental music.
And so the only instrumental group that they had was the Aggie band on that campus.
And I started the first year I was there, I started an Aggie concert band
which they had not had.
And I also revived the Aggieland Orchestra, which is a big dance band.
And so these people began to come see me.
And being an old music educator, I could see that they really had
a legitimate reason to want to do it.
They just wanted to play.
They had nowhere to go.
There were four Allstate bassoon players on the campus at that time and just, they were meeting secretly and doing a bunch of stuff and I could see a bunch of trouble coming.
So I went to see my boss in 19, I believe it was in 73 was John Coldis and I went to visit with John.
And then he sent me to see Dr. Williams.
And we all agreed that we needed something to take the pressure off of them because anybody that was in the Aggie band had to be in the Corps.
Okay.
So they gave me permission to start a university symphonic band, which I did.
And we called it the Texas A&M University Symphonic Band.
And I hired a guy named Joe McMullen, he was going to do that, and I was going to continue with the Aggieland Orchestra.
So then we had
And then the drumming bugle corps, we put them on a very impressive rehearsal schedule.
You can monitor them a little more closely.
So then all of a sudden we had five groups.
And this was not acceptable by some of the Aggie band members at first.
They thought I was a traitor or something.
I don't know what they thought.
But after they could see what was going on, a lot of them played in it and it's still going.
And last year they took a tour to Ireland and I think next year they're going to Europe somewhere.
But anyway this in no way interfered with the functions of the Aggie band and if anything it took a lot of pressure off saying that's the only band you have out in the place.
No it isn't here.
So anyway, it worked out real good.
And so the facilities and everything was just fine.
And the band hall was excellent and had the field right there.
And all the guys lived right there in the dorm.
And no one could ever ask for a better band situation than that anywhere in the world.
And when you arrived, you didn't have to put out any fires.
Nothing was broken.
There was a smooth transition.
As far as I, yes.
Yes, you could say that.
There's no...
Because I did not come here to change the Aggie band.
And in your opinion, or no one else's opinion, did it need any changes?
No.
It was continuity.
That was the one thing that we made clear, and it happened, that I didn't come here to make waves or change anything.
And you know when you're up there close to number one and you don't do well, there's not one way you can go.
Now you're talking about pressure on a little old fellow, a little country boy.
I had pressure.
And so of course nobody, everybody thought it was going to the dogs and it didn't.
And we increased the numbers and the main thing we did was improve on the playing.
and more variety of music.
We passed out, I think the second year, by the second year we'd pass out 45 tunes.
We'd have short versions for variety.
And for the first time ever though, you know, you don't want to really, you do something different and not really change anything.
And one of the greatest experiences I think I had, I wrote a
